snippet.textDisplay:
Mr. Night shamalama ding dong made like 3 or 4 good films that I have seen. Signs was dope as hell at the time, 6th sense is a classic and the village was pretty interesting, a great premise, just not the best execution.
Edit: I might be the only person on earth who hasn't seen all of the avatar show, only a handful of episodes.
Edit: oooooh wow. Wowwwee. Now I see why everyone says this movie was so disrespectful. My lord, did they do nothing right? Lol

snippet.textDisplay:
You know what drives me crazy about this movie, probably more than it should?

They pronounce Aang like "ong" and Sokka like "sew-kuh".

You guys did watch the original series before making the movie, right? You heard how the names were pronounced? How did you get them wrong when they're said a bajillion times in the original series, always with the same pronunciation!?
snippet.textOriginal:
You know what drives me crazy about this movie, probably more than it should?

They pronounce Aang like "ong" and Sokka like "sew-kuh". 

You guys did watch the original series before making the movie, right? You heard how the names were pronounced? How did you get them wrong when they're said a bajillion times in the original series, always with the same pronunciation!?

snippet.textDisplay:
From warriors learn courage,
And wisdom from the sage.
If you truly seek God’s grace,
Ride with the heavenly carriage.

Oh, if a tree could wander
and move with foot and wings!
It would not suffer the axe blows
and not the pain of saws!

Did I not say to you, "Go not there, for I am your friend; in this
mirage of annihilation I am the fountain of life?"

Have no doubts because of trouble nor be thou discomfited;
For the water of life’s fountain springeth from a gloomy bed.

Did I not say to you, " They will implant in you ugly qualities
so that you will forget that I am the source of purity to you?"

I am the power of flight.
DryobatesScalaris
snippet.textOriginal:

so that you will forget that I am the source of purity to you?"

DryobatesScalaris

snippet.textDisplay:
Is the original star wars trillogy propaganda against the empire?

I was thinking that while watching the video. It's not new to have a scapist movie also have political commentary. But besides that, should we treat a blockbuster as a philosophy text in the first place? I'm not saying films can't express strong ideas, even philosophical ones, but I mean, this isn't Bergman or Godard.
And yes, blockbuster can have artistical value. But we know from Adorno that hollywood is making money, it's not trying to make art. The cultural industry does that to culture, and of course hollywood is the big producer of canned cultural products.
I think the video was not really self aware about the place of blockbusters (and hollywood in general) in the political economuy of culture.

Besides that, I don't know if I agree with the scapist / ideological split you created. Nor your definition of ideology and propaganda. Ideology isn't merely explicit political agenda. Zizek talks about an aspect of ideology: being what is not questioned, what is implicit in the text and goes as true without further analysis. So I agree with you when you say Avatar defends an specific political idea, and the movie imposes more than discusses it. In that the movie is extremely ideological.

But let's go further. Can a film have no ideology? Does a "unbiased movie" exist? Only if a movie can explore every single aspect of politics. A movie will have presunptions, things wich will not be questioned, so it will be ideological. So when a movie is about a political question, it can try to be unbiassed, but it will only fail, since it will not explore deeply every aspect of political thought. In this case, it will be propaganda of some sort.

For example the DND movie. It's a clearly ideological movie. There's a lot of political choices in that movie. For example we begin the movie by getting to know the protagonists are encarcerated. We're lead to cheer for emprisioned characters, wich pressuposes the encarcerating system is not perfect and can punish good people, innocent people even. This is purely political.

So after all this, I couldn't stop thinking... so what? Yes it's ideological and it's propaganda for the ideology of the 'good guys". So is Star wars and the DND movie. The video itself is purely ideological. The idea that movies should be 'unbiassed' and 'not propaganda', but why? art should not be propaganda, what's the good thing about it? what's the bad thing about it? What's the implied social role of art ? Even when talking about the ideology of avatar the video was really ideological.

I've watched your videos for years now, and i will keep watching i love them. But I felt that this essay didn't go further enough

snippet.textDisplay:
I loved the first Avatar film, at a very emotional level.

It speaks to my inner pantheist / animist / panpsychist.

So what if the story is generic? It speaks to me, at a very deep & profound level... and that's all that matters.

So what if the distinction between good & evil is very black & white. The same applies to Star Wars, and everone seems to love the original Star Wars Trilogy.

In a previous life, I watched Avatar (extended version) every year on my birthday, often combined with an empathogen like MDMA and/or a psychedelic like LSD, as some sort of cleansing ritual.

I never understood the hate this movie gets.

The sequel is crap, though. James Cameron, like eg. also Tim Burton or Ridley Scott, seems to have lost his magic...
snippet.textOriginal:
I loved the first Avatar film, at a very emotional level. 

It speaks to my inner pantheist / animist / panpsychist.

So what if the story is generic? It speaks to me, at a very deep & profound level... and that's all that matters.

So what if the distinction between good & evil is very black & white. The same applies to Star Wars, and everone seems to love the original Star Wars Trilogy.

In a previous life, I watched Avatar (extended version) every year on my birthday, often combined with an empathogen like MDMA and/or a psychedelic like LSD, as some sort of cleansing ritual.

I never understood the hate this movie gets.

The sequel is crap, though. James Cameron, like eg. also Tim Burton or Ridley Scott, seems to have lost his magic...

snippet.textDisplay:
I actually had a perfectly good answer for why I didn't like Avatar:

Because Jake Sully never had a real conflict.

Pete Docter said it really well in an interview about the climax of UP - "if the choice is too easy, then it isn't a choice."

And the choice presented to Jake, was too easy. There was literally nothing tying him to Earth at all. There was no real emotional conflict for him at any point.Think about it. The events of the story seriously ask him:

Would he rather protect the interests of a soulless megacorp and its psychotic paramilitary force who don't see him as anything but a tool to help them get to stripmining Pandora as fast as possible, and then go home to an Earth where his entire family is dead, he lives in an apartment the size of a closet, pollution is rampant to the point where the oceans are poisoned and all the animal species are dead and food is grown on algae farms, and the rest of the planet is reduced to overcrowded, grey hyper-urban squalor where poverty, loneliness and general misery are just facts of life, and also he's crippled/paraplegic?

Orrrrrrr would he rather live on an untouched paradise-planet as part of a tribe of peaceful, perfect, all-knowing, literally flawless people with a literal connection to the planet itself where he wouldn't ever want for anything and also in a healthy body which ALSO happens to let him have sex with the hot blue cat girl who is now in love with him?

Why wouldn't he take the latter choice?

Some of us could explain why we disliked Avatar just fine, thank you very much.
snippet.textOriginal:
I actually had a perfectly good answer for why I didn't like Avatar:

Because Jake Sully never had a real conflict.

Pete Docter said it really well in an interview about the climax of UP - "if the choice is too easy, _then it isn't a choice."_

And the choice presented to Jake, _was too easy._ There was literally nothing tying him to Earth at all. There was no real emotional conflict for him at any point.Think about it. The events of the story seriously ask him: 

Would he rather protect the interests of a soulless megacorp and its psychotic paramilitary force who don't see him as anything but a tool to help them get to stripmining Pandora as fast as possible, and then go home to an Earth where his entire family is dead, he lives in an apartment the size of a closet, pollution is rampant to the point where the oceans are poisoned and all the animal species are dead and food is grown on algae farms, and the rest of the planet is reduced to overcrowded, grey hyper-urban squalor where poverty, loneliness and general misery are just facts of life, and also he's crippled/paraplegic?

_Orrrrrrr_ would he rather live on an untouched paradise-planet as part of a tribe of peaceful, perfect, all-knowing, literally flawless people with a literal connection to the planet itself where he wouldn't ever want for anything and also in a healthy body which ALSO happens to let him have sex with the hot blue cat girl who is now in love with him?

Why _wouldn't_ he take the latter choice?

Some of us could explain why we disliked Avatar _just fine,_ thank you very much.

snippet.textDisplay: All the movie aspects of this aside, I personally think the reason the Avatar gets so much hate it because it essentially tells the story of  colonization and there are a lot of racist people in the world that will never like something that basically calls out the truly awful things their racist views allow to happen. It also explains why most people can't give a solid reason for their dislike... Racists never want to admit they are racist for some reason. Honestly, the non specific nature of the movie's hate just makes it even more obvious that they are upset over a narrative that actively and correctly frames the role of colonization, plus the colonizers lose on top of that. The movie solidifies in no uncertain terms that the colonizer is the one who is wrong and immoral. I don't know of any racist who would fall in love with a movie that basically tells them their beliefs are the evil...

snippet.textDisplay:
I like your idea of having the 'Unobtainium' be vital to Earth's survival. More nuanced explorations would be to have the Na'vi have a faction that was expansionist and a bit corrupt. They could be the way Earth got their initial foothold on Pandora. Maybe they could have captured slaves from the others and sold them to the Earthlings for them to develop the Avatar technology in the first place. They traded for medicine and technology. The expansionists used these new concepts but quickly adapted the non sustainable and environmentally exploitative and destructive way of life. The rebels could be the parts of Na'vi society that are able to continue trade after winning their independence, but are able to incorporate the new medicine and technologies into the society in a sustainable and environmentally harmonious way.

The sequel could have been about the civil unrest between hold outs of the old way of life, hold overs from the expansionists and the progressive rebels having to try to balance the need for continued military enforcement to guide integration and progress for all factions without falling into the same pitfalls of the Expansionists. They would struggle with their desire for peace and harmony; and a stronger presence, autonomy and sovereignty a in galactic society.

The expansionists used these new concepts but quickly adapted the non sustainable and environmentally exploitative and destructive way of life. The rebels could be the parts of Na'vi society that are able to continue trade after winning their independence, but are able to incorporate the new medicine and technologies into the society in a sustainable and environmentally harmonious way.

They would struggle with their desire for peace and harmony; and a stronger presence, autonomy and sovereignty a in galactic society.

snippet.textDisplay: I think a good example of complex storytelling about the whole of a sentient species would be The Day the Earth Stood Still. Humanity as a whole is judged and found wanting. But the judge is made to see that the matter of Humanity's right to exist autonomously is much more complex because we're not just capable of Hate, Murder, Exploitation, Destruction, Depravity and Chaos, but also capable of Love, Bravery, Compassion, Posterity, Divinity, and Creativity.
snippet.textOriginal: I think a good example of complex storytelling about the whole of a sentient species would be The Day the Earth Stood Still. Humanity as a whole is judged and found wanting. But the judge is made to see that the matter of Humanity's right to exist autonomously is much more complex because we're not just capable of Hate, Murder, Exploitation, Destruction, Depravity and Chaos, but also capable of Love, Bravery, Compassion, Posterity, Divinity, and Creativity.

snippet.textDisplay:
Really the Na'vi are modelled to represent a sort of "model minority" in the movies. Not in the sense that we might usually hear about in regards to real world relations but in the sense that they're written to be unendingly sympathetic in our eyes so that there's no way anyone could argue that the humans are in any kind of "right". Which is a deeply flawed idea because like, no matter what indigenous tribes may have commited, none of those actions made us europeans justified in our colonisation and genocide of their groups.
Genocide is never deserved and I think portraying the Na'vi as perfect sets unrealistic morals for the movies message. Would James Cameron not have depicted the acts commited against the Na'vi as immoral if the Na'vi themselves also commited immoral acts? Like I don't think so, this is obviously just a result of somewhat lazy writing and an oversimplified worldview, but I feel that it's always an important point to bring into these discussions; why should people have to defend their right not to be colonized?

Genocide is never deserved and I think portraying the Na'vi as perfect sets unrealistic morals for the movies message. The first movie is somewhat vague but they’re still very much like stereotypical indigenous american depictions, but the second move is blatantly drawing from Pacifca people, and specifically the Māori. It’s just the Nobel savage trope, but blue

snippet.textDisplay:
Awfully rigid thinking.
Central to the show's identity is the idea that the ways of each nation are not locked into that one place- each person can and should learn from as many sources as possible. This is how aang, zuko, iroh, and many others learned to be more balanced people.
Ty Lee fights in a way that seems like an airbender, but so does Azula during the eclipse. They learned evasiveness and responsiveness by being open to new ideas, not by being locked into the airbender nation.
snippet.textOriginal:
Awfully rigid thinking. 
Central to the show's identity is the idea that the ways of each nation are not locked into that one place- each person can and should learn from as many sources as possible. This is how aang, zuko, iroh, and many others learned to be more balanced people. 
Ty Lee fights in a way that seems like an airbender, but so does Azula during the eclipse. They learned evasiveness and responsiveness by being open to new ideas, not by being locked into the airbender nation.

snippet.textDisplay: While I support this theory, using 3 members of the SAME family looking alike as an argument for why shes not from that whole nation is.. kinda a weak point. "You cant possibly be from china! You look nothing like him, his sister, and his father!" As if that whole nation looks like that singular family. Also you may say "well mai isnt" correct, but she is from a royal family. And royal families love getting close and mixing their bloodlines. So its just a weak argument in my opinion.
